unnormalised: Someone asked me the other day about property prices in Bangalore, and it got me thinking. It's a complicated question! You see ads claiming "2BHK flat for just ₹45 lakhs!" but is that *really* what you end up paying? Not always, bhai. There are so many hidden costs in the real estate market.
normalised: Someone asked me the other day about property prices in Bangalore, and it got me thinking. It's a complicated question! You see ads claiming "two B-H-K flat for just rupee forty five lakhs!" but is that really what you end up paying? Not always, bhai. There are so many hidden costs in the real estate market.

unnormalised: First, you have the base price. Okay, that's the advertised ₹45L. Then add the registration charges, which can be around 5-7% of the property value. So, immediately, that's another ₹2-3 lakhs. Plus, there's stamp duty to consider. Don't forget GST, which is applicable on under-construction properties. Suddenly, that “affordable” flat is creeping closer to ₹50 lakhs.
normalised: First, you have the base price. Okay, that's the advertised rupee forty five lakhs. Then add the registration charges, which can be around five to seven percent of the property value. So, immediately, that's another rupee two to three lakhs. Plus, there's stamp duty to consider. Don't forget G-S-T, which is applicable on under-construction properties. Suddenly, that "affordable" flat is creeping closer to rupee fifty lakhs.

unnormalised: Then you have the "amenities" charges. The builder might say ₹2 lakhs for the swimming pool, gym, and clubhouse access. Some even charge extra for car parking – could be another ₹50k-₹1L, depending on the location and type of parking. And don't forget the floor rise charges, if you are opting for the 15th floor. These can bump up the price significantly. The final price is usually very different from the advertised price.
normalised: Then you have the "amenities" charges. The builder might say rupee two lakhs for the swimming pool, gym, and clubhouse access. Some even charge extra for car parking – could be another rupee fifty thousand to rupee one lakh, depending on the location and type of parking. And don't forget the floor rise charges, if you are opting for the fifteenth floor. These can bump up the price significantly. The final price is usually very different from the advertised price.

unnormalised: So, next time you see that tempting ad for a "1000 sq ft apartment for Rs. 6000/sq ft," remember to dig deeper and ask about ALL the charges. Do your research properly. It's better to be aware upfront than to get a nasty surprise later!
